item.title: Wavefront Propagation
item.content:encoded:
This post intends to be a quick guide on the most important equations for computing free space propagation of a wavefront in the Fresnel regime, and how to do it properly.

Helmholtz equation and elementary waves​

First, some background. Consider a monochromatic wave ψ\psiψ in vacuum. It is governed by Helmholtz equation:

∇2ψ+k2ψ=0\nabla^2\psi + k^2 \psi = 0 ∇2ψ+k2ψ=0

which has two solutions which we call elementary waves. These are:

Plane Waves

ψ(r)=Aexp⁡(−jk⋅r)=Aexp⁡[−j(kxx+kyy+kzz)]\psi(\mathbf{r}) = A \exp{(-j \mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{r})} = A \exp{[-j (k_x x + k_y y + k_z z)]}ψ(r)=Aexp(−jk⋅r)=Aexp[−j(kx​x+ky​y+kz​z)]

Spherical Waves

ψ(r)=Arexp⁡(−jkr)\psi(\mathbf{r}) = \frac{A}{r} \exp{(-j k r)} ψ(r)=rA​exp(−jkr)

which names indicates that the wavefronts (i.e. the surfaces of constant phase) are either planes or spheres. These are the most basic waves there are. Keep in mind that spherical waves are the kind of wave produced by point sources.

Naturally, what we encounter waves that are way more complex than elementary waves. Luckily, we can make things easier by what is called the Angular Spectrum of waves.

Angular Spectrum Method (ASM)​

An arbitrary wavefront U1(x,y)U_1(x,y)U1​(x,y) can be decomposed into plane wave components:

Raleigh-Sommerfeld Diffraction​

U2(x2,y2)=zjλ∫∫SU1(x1,y1)exp⁡(jkr12)r122dx1dy1U_2(x_2,y_2) = \frac{z}{j \lambda} \int \int_S U_1(x_1,y_1) \frac{\exp{(j k r_{12})}}{r_{12}^2} dx_1 dy_1U2​(x2​,y2​)=jλz​∫∫S​U1​(x1​,y1​)r122​exp(jkr12​)​dx1​dy1​

where

r12=z2+(x2−x1)2+(y2−y1)2r_{12} = \sqrt{z^2 + (x_2 - x_1)^2 + (y_2 - y_1)^2}r12​=z2+(x2​−x1​)2+(y2​−y1​)2​

Approximations​

Paraboloidal

U(x2,y2)=eikLiλL∫∫−∞+∞U(x1,y1)eik2L[(x2−x1)2+(y2−y1)2]dx1dy1U(x_2,y_2) = \frac{e^{ikL}}{i \lambda L} \int \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} U (x_1,y_1) e^{ \frac{i k}{2 L}\left[{(x_2-x_1)^2+(y_2-y_1)^2} \right]} dx_1 dy_1U(x2​,y2​)=iλLeikL​∫∫−∞+∞​U(x1​,y1​)e2Lik​[(x2​−x1​)2+(y2​−y1​)2]dx1​dy1​

Gaussian

A=1A = 1A=1

Calculation of the Fresnel diffraction integral​

Expanding

U(x2,y2)=eikLiλLeik2L[x22+y22]∫∫−∞+∞U(x1,y1)eik2L[x12+y12]eik2L(x2x1+y2y1)dx1dy1U(x_2,y_2) = \frac{e^{ikL}}{i \lambda L} e^{ \frac{i k}{2 L}\left[{x_2^2+y_2^2} \right]} \int \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} U (x_1,y_1) e^{ \frac{i k}{2 L} \left[{x_1^2+y_1^2} \right] } e^{ \frac{i k}{2 L}{(x_2 x_1+y_2 y_1)} }dx_1 dy_1U(x2​,y2​)=iλLeikL​e2Lik​[x22​+y22​]∫∫−∞+∞​U(x1​,y1​)e2Lik​[x12​+y12​]e2Lik​(x2​x1​+y2​y1​)dx1​dy1​

Impulse Response (IR)​

Equation XXX is nothing more than a convolution of UUU with the following impulse responde function hhh

h(x,y)=eikziλzeik2z[x2+y2] h(x,y) = \frac{e^{ikz}}{i \lambda z} e^{ \frac{i k}{2 z}\left[{x^2+y^2} \right]}h(x,y)=iλzeikz​e2zik​[x2+y2]

This convolution can be calculated in Fourier space as

U(x2,y2)=F−1FU(x1,y1)H(fx1,fy1) U(x_2,y_2) = \mathcal{F}^{-1}{ \mathcal{F}{ U(x_1,y_1) } H(f_{x1},f_{y1}) }U(x2​,y2​)=F−1FU(x1​,y1​)H(fx1​,fy1​)

where

H(fx1,fy1)=Fh(x1,y1)=ejkzexp⁡[jπλz(fx2+fy2)] H(f_{x1},f_{y1}) = \mathcal{F}{h(x_1,y_1)} = e^{jkz} \exp{[j \pi \lambda z (f_{x}^2+f_{y}^2)]}H(fx1​,fy1​)=Fh(x1​,y1​)=ejkzexp[jπλz(fx2​+fy2​)]

Single Fourier Transform (SFT)​

U(x2,y2)=eikziλzeik2z[x22+y22]FU(x1,y1)eik2z[x12+y12] U(x_2,y_2) = \frac{e^{ikz}}{i \lambda z} e^{ \frac{i k}{2 z}\left[{x_2^2+y_2^2} \right]} \mathcal{F}{ U(x_1,y_1) e^{ \frac{i k}{2 z} \left[{x_1^2+y_1^2} \right] } }U(x2​,y2​)=iλzeikz​e2zik​[x22​+y22​]FU(x1​,y1​)e2zik​[x12​+y12​]

Although mathematically identical, they are numerically different.

Chirp functions:

C1=eik2z(x12+y12)C_1 = e^{ \frac{i k}{2 z} \left({x_1^2+y_1^2} \right) } C1​=e2zik​(x12​+y12​) C2=ejπλz(fx2+fy2)C_2 = e^{j \pi \lambda z (f_{x}^2+f_{y}^2)}C2​=ejπλz(fx2​+fy2​)

When to use which?​

Now, to the practical side: how do you choose which to use? In that case one may use a rule of thumb (although for the details I'd recommend taking a close look at the references below):

CriteriaSamplingComment
Δx>λzL\Delta x > \frac{\lambda z}{L}Δx>Lλz​TF: oversampled. IR: undersampledIR method causes periodic copies. TF is the method of choice. Observation plane width will be limited to width D+λz/ΔxD + \lambda z / \Delta xD+λz/Δx
Δx=λzL\Delta x = \frac{\lambda z}{L}Δx=Lλz​both TF and IR: critical samplingTF and IR are identical
Δx<λzL\Delta x < \frac{\lambda z}{L}Δx<Lλz​TF: undersampled. IR: oversampledIt depends. Needs to evaluate if source bandwidth satisfies B≤L2λzB \le \frac{L}{2 \lambda z}B≤2λzL​. If yes, use TF. Otherwise, IR may be better.

Fresnel scaling theorem​

What if you have a point source (i.e. spherical waves), causing the beam to diverge?

The 2-step Fresnel propagator​

U(x2,y2)=L2L1exp⁡(jkz)exp⁡[−jk2zL1−L2L2(x22+y22)]F−1exp⁡[−jπλzL1L2(fx12+fy12)]FU1(x1,y1)exp⁡[jk2zL1−L2L1(x12+y12)]\begin{align*} U(x_2,y_2) & = \frac{L_2}{L_1} \exp{(j k z)} \exp{\left[ -j \frac{k}{2z} \frac{L_1-L_2}{L_2} (x_2^2+y_2^2) \right]} \\ & \mathcal{F}^{-1}{\exp{[-j\pi \lambda z \frac{L_1}{L_2}(f_{x1}^2+f_{y1}^2)]} \mathcal{F}{ U_1(x_1,y_1) \exp{[j \frac{k}{2z}\frac{L_1-L_2}{L_1}(x_1^2+y_1^2)]}} } \end{align*}U(x2​,y2​)​=L1​L2​​exp(jkz)exp[−j2zk​L2​L1​−L2​​(x22​+y22​)]F−1exp[−jπλzL2​L1​​(fx12​+fy12​)]FU1​(x1​,y1​)exp[j2zk​L1​L1​−L2​​(x12​+y12​)]​
